title: San Ciriaco culture
text:
The San Ciriaco culture, sometimes also called San Ciriaco Phase, is a middle <a href="Neolithic%20Europe">neolithic</a>, <a href="Pre-Nuragic%20Sardinia">pre-Nuragic culture</a> from <a href="Sardinia">Sardinia</a> and roughly dates to the second half of the 5th millennium BC (4500-4000 BC). It is named after a locality in the territory of <a href="Terralba">Terralba</a>, in the <a href="province%20of%20Oristano">province of Oristano</a>.
The economy of the San Ciriaco people was predominantly agricultural using the same plant and animal species as the preceding <a href="Bonu%20Ighinu%20culture">Bonu Ighinu culture</a>. San Ciriaco ceramics encompass well-fired and thin-walled vessels with polished surfaces varying in colour from beige to black. Vessels exhibit angular or carinated shapes, possess slightly rounded or flat bases and are undecorated. At <a href="Monte%20Arci">Monte Arci</a> larger workshops hint towards an intensified use of <a href="obsidian">obsidian</a> while imported flint from the <a href="Gargano%20Peninsula">Gargano peninsula</a> found in cist 1 of the Li Muri necropolis at <a href="Arzachena">Arzachena</a> documents far reaching contacts.
While small artificial caves continued to be used for burials, now more elaborated underground rock-cut tombs, so called <a href="Hypogeum">hypogea</a>, were built, placing Sardinia well into the <a href="Megalith">megalithic</a> context of the <a href="%C4%A6al%20Saflieni%20Hypogeum">western mediterranean</a>. Some like tomb 10 at Santa Pedru reach a considerable size (15 x 7 m) and consist of five chambers. Stone <a href="Cist">cists</a> covered by <a href="Cairn">cairns</a> were also built.
